original_title: 1,000 tonne crane unloaded at Sri Lanka’s China backed port
original_body_lines: CONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s China backed Hambantota Port said a crawler crane weighing 1000 tonnes had been safely unloaded after being shipped from Japan, which will use to erect wind turbines.
“It is the first time Japan has exported such a large crane,” said Keerthi Manthrirathna, the proprietor of Rainbow Lanka, a crane rental company in Sri Lanka, said in the statment.
“There are only a few cranes of this capacity in Japan, and only three are available in the whole of South Asia,”
The crane was built by Germany’s Liebherr brand and was being used in construction projects in Japan before being shipped to Sri Lanka.
“The crawler crane, which consisted of 1000 tons of components, was unloaded by HIP within a day,” the statement said.
The cargo was then transferred to 42 trucks, which took the equipment by road in two days to Mannar for assembly, where the wind turbines are being erected at the Hiruras power project.
The wind farm will have 20 turbines made by Denmark-based Vestas, with a total capcity of 100 MegaWatts.
The plant is expected to generate approximately 400 gigawatt-hours of electricity per year. (Colombo/Mar 20/2023)
